member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.FieldAttribute.IsReadOnlyByDefault
member.summary:
Indicates whether the generated field or property is implicitly read-only. If the property is , the generated data member (auto-impl'ed propertys or fields) will be modified by keyword if all following conditions are true:
The type is a , , or (will be included in future C# version)
The type is not marked with keyword
However, sometimes we should use non- member as fields or auto-impl'ed properties, but we cannot modify it. By setting the property with value, to avoid the source generator marking the generated member as .
member.remarks: This property is by default.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ParameterTargetAttribute.Accessibility
member.summary: Indicates the accessibility of the generated member.

remarks.para:
This property controls the case when you want to customize the accessibility of generated member. For example, the value is "private", the generated member will automatically insert the accessibility modifier into property declaration:
private int Parameter { get; } = parameter;
Also, you can append not only 1 word. For example, the combination "protected internal readonly unsafe" is also acceptable.
By default, the accessibility is for fields and for properties.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ParameterTargetAttribute.NamingRule
member.summary: Indicates the naming rule of the generated member name.

remarks.para:
The syntax of this property can be described as two parts:
A verbatim symbol @ ("At" symbol, may contain an extra character < or >: <@ or >@)
Characters used in a valid identifier

For example, if you want to set a generated property is named like xxxTargetProperty where the xxx is the name of the generated property, you can set this property as value "@TargetProperty". Then the generated property will be like:
public int ParameterTargetProperty { get; } = parameter;
By default, the naming rule is "_<@" for fields, and ">@" for properties.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.PropertyAttribute
member.summary: Indicates the backing generated member of this primary constructor is a property.

summary.para: Indicates the extra setter expression. The expression is same declaration as auto-implemented properties.

For example, if the property is declared as public object? Property { get; private set; }, the setter expression will be "private set". By default, this value will be , which means the target property does not contain a setter.

This type doesn't use any extra syntax to constraint such usage, but C# will check for it. The type will include a constraint that implements the interface itself to declare such "self constraint" usage: interface ISelfType<TSelf> where TSelf : ISelfType<TSelf> In addition, the type should be named TSelf in order to tell type parameters with the others.

member.name: P:System.Linq.Providers.ILinqMethod`2.SupportsQuerySyntax
member.summary: Indicates whether the methods defined in type support for query syntax also. By default, the value is .
member.remarks:
All possible query clauses are:
Query syntax Equivalent method
element collection N/A
element1 collection1
element2 collection2
condition
variable = expression
{ variable | expression } [ variable]
{ variable | expression } ?
{ variable | expression }
{ v1 | e1 }, { v2 | e2 } ? ...
{ v1 | e1 }, { v2 | e2 } ...
variable { variable | expression } [ variable]
expression expression [ variable]
variable collection previousVariable variable
variable2 collection2 variable1 variable2 joinedGroup

feature.name: scoped-keyword
feature.para: The keyword means the argument and local variable can only be used inside the method. This means you cannot use this variable and argument outside the scope, such as new RefStructType(scoped_variable), return scoped_variable and field = scoped_variable. Such expressions may store the variables, unsafely expanding the variable's lifecycle.

member.name: M:System.Resources.SR.RegisterResourceManager``1
member.summary: Register a new resource manager for the current assembly calling this method.

typeparam.name: TResourceManagerProvider
typeparam.para: The type of the resource manager provider.

This type should point to a generated type, bound with your resource dictionary manifest file (*.resx), named like the file name of it. For example, if you create a resource dictionary manifest file called Resource.resx, a generated type will be named Resource. You should pass in this type (Resource here) as type argument to this method.

member.exception: Throws when the current calling assembly doesn't contain any resource manager.
